This award strives to conserve biodiversity and manage natural resources in ways that maintain their long-term viability and preserve their potential to meet the needs of present and future generations. Activities include combating illegal and corrupt exploitation of natural resources and the control of invasive species. This includes Project activities will 1) produce guidance and recommendations that address key drivers of wildlife product supply and demand, 2) strengthen wildlife traffic law enforcement and monitoring, and 3) fully develop the National Strategy to Combat Wildlife Traffic through systematic analyses of information and lessons learned, and multi-agency and public-private sector cooperation. Specific activities include a) assessing rural Amazonian communities' involvement in wildlife extraction and development of recommendations for public outreach, b) assessinig urban public perceptions about cities' inhabitants' involvement in wildlife trafficking, c) piloting a social media outreach project and draw lessons and recommendations, d) identifying critical wildlife trafficking value chain links and georgraphic areas in Peru through a systematic review and analysis of available information, e) designing a unified database and standar data management protocols, f) identifying key law enforcement interventions, g) evaluating the legal framework and organizational structure to identify opportunities for inter-agency cooperation and create inter-agency cooperation platforms, and h) support government officials in the development of a National Strategy to Combat Wildlife Traffic in Peru..

description.narrative: U.S. assistance builds the capacity of Peruvian institutions to combat transnational organized crime more effectively, improve citizen security and social inclusion, sustainably manage Peru's diverse and fragile environment, and expand the benefits of Peru's economic progress to more of its citizens. Peru is one of the world's largest cocaine producers, a major money laundering center, a principal source of illegally logged timber and illegally mined gold, and the largest source of counterfeit U.S. currency worldwide. While economic growth has slowed for the past two years due to a slump in international commodity prices and the failure to implement second generation reforms, successive Peruvian governments have pursued judicious, market-based economic policies yielding over a decade of economic growth averaging five percent, which has halved poverty rates, reduced infant mortality, increased lifespans, and expanded access to education. Peru is one of the United States' most steadfast democratic partners in the region, and the continuation of bi-lateral assistance advances U.S. national security and economic interests.
